quote: The point is to die like men -- like Travis and Crockett. Doing our duty right up until the end.
Like Travis and Crockett...
One more door...
Doctor Bashir's regaining consciousness, captain.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: How's Miles?
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm fine.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Did you get the information you were looking for?
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I'm afraid not. We have to go back in...
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: That would not be wise, Doctor.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan's dying. We can't risk losing you as well.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan's dying. We can't risk losing you as well.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He can't die. Not yet!
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Cordrazine. Ten milligrams.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: His alpha waves are attenuating.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Cortical stimulator.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: You're not getting away from me that easily, Sloan.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Amplify the resonance frequency ten percent.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: No response. His neurosynaptic activity is failing.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I can see that. Fifteen milligrams neurotropan.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Come on, Sloan. Come on back.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Complete neural failure.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: No!
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He's dead, Doctor.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: It's over, Julian. He's gone...
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: And so's any hope of curing Odo.
scene: 37   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: ... I wish I had better news. I'm sorry.
I understand, doctor. You've done all you could -- more than I would've thought possible and I appreciate it.
Is there anything I can do to make you more comfortable?
Thank you, but right now I simply want to be alone.
Of course.
How'd he take it?
Better than I would.
I need some sleep. So do you.
Look, Julian --
I know -- I did all I could. It's small comfort.
"It was the best of times... "
"... it was the worst of times."
It's the first line of the book.
That's right. So why is it on page two hundred and ninety-four?
Must be a misprint... the entire book starts over again.
It can't be. Ezri loaned it to me -- it used to be Jadzia's and I know for a fact that she read it.
You and Ezri are exchanging books?
Forget about that. Don't you see what's going on?
She's playing a practical joke.
No. It's Sloan. We're still inside his mind.
What? These are my quarters -- Keiko's sleeping in the other room.
No, she's not. Sloan is drawing on our memories... making us think we're back on the station. That's why the book is incomplete... because I hadn't finished reading it.
And because you didn't know what happened after page two-ninety- four...
He couldn't fill in the rest of the story.
He's trying to keep us from looking for the cure.
Which means we must've been very close to finding it.
The door -- the one we were about to open when we woke up --the cure must be in there.
What's going on?
Sloan's dying. His mind's shutting down. We're running out of time.
This is it!
Are you sure?
I can tell.
Sloan?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Welcome to Section Thirty-one, Gentlemen...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You know what we're here for.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You don't really expect me to help you...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You sure you want to throw that one away... ?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I'm looking for medical information, not surveillance reports...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: That's not just any report... it's on Garish Inyo.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Former President Inyo?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: The one and only.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: My God... Thirty-one had a man inside his cabinet...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Just one of the little nuggets lying around in this... once-tidy room. You'd be amazed at what you could find in here.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Don't let him distract you.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Current operations on Chronos... Chancellor Martok would love to get his hands on this...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Radodine, lidestolinine, asporanine, adenine... This is it.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I think it's time to get out of here.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Hold on a moment.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: What for?
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: These files contain all of Sloan's memories of Section Thirty-one. With this information... we could destroy the entire organization.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: That'll have to wait.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: It's not that simple, Chief. There's no building... no room like this in the real world. Section Thirty-one has no headquarters. These files... they exist only in the minds of a very select group of people. I happen to be one of them...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: If you really want to destroy Section Thirty-one... it's now or never.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: He's right. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity, Miles. We can't pass it up.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Leave me alone --
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Listen to me -- he's trying to keep us here. He wants us to die with him. And if we die -- Odo dies too!
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: All my secrets are yours for the taking, doctor... if you want them badly enough.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Odo needs you, Julian. He's counting on you.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: You're making a terrible mistake, doctor...
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: I don't think so.
scene: 47   INT. SECTION THIRTY-ONE (REDRESS DEFIANT MESS HALL)

quote: Julian, are you with us?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Ezri... you look beautiful.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Were you able to find the cure?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I think so, but there's only one way to know for sure...
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Sloan?
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: He died about two minutes ago... Almost took you with him.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Julian, next time you take a trip into someone's mind... you're going alone.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: Right.
scene: 48   INT. SCIENCE LAB - CLOSE ON BASHIR

quote: I should warn you... you might feel some discomfort.
If you mean it's going to be painful, just say so.
It's going to be painful.
All right then. Go ahead.
How long before Odo's up and around?
His morphogenic matrix needs time to heal. He should be his old self again in a few days.
I knew Quark was hoarding a bottle of the good stuff in here somewhere.
This is older than I am.
What?
I can't believe I'm drinking with a child.
To aging gracefully?
Very funny. To Odo.
Wow.
Wow is right.
Let me ask you something... if you'd had time to read more of the data in Sloan's mind... you really think we could've brought down Section Thirty-one?
We'll never know, will we? One thing's for sure -- Sloan knew it was the perfect bait... that I wouldn't be able to resist it. Luckily he failed to consider one thing...
What's that?
You. To Miles Edward O'Brien.
To friendship.
To friendship.
We already did that.
Let's do it again.
I've got to get home. Keiko's holding dinner for me.
This late?
She's a helluva woman.
That's why you love her.
That's right. That's why I love her.
You wanna come?
Sure.
What's funny is where the files were located: right there in Ops protocols.
The encryption system was extremely easy to break.
So they wanted us to find these.
Or they didn't care.
Well, there's nothing of strategic value here. Just personal logs and some files on Bajoran terrorists. But it is a glimpse into the Cardassian mind.
You might want to warn Kira before she sees her file.
Warn me about what?
Oh, ah, Dax and Chief O'Brien discovered some of the last Prefect's personal files. There's a file on you, but you may find it... disappointing.
I'm a big girl, Commander.
Bashir to Sisko!
Sisko here.
I'm at Airlock Fourteen, Commander. I think you'd better get down here.
What's the problem, Doctor?
I was about to begin off-loading some medical specimens from the Bajoran transport... and... well... The Kai is here!
Kai... Opaka? Why would she be here?
She says you once offered her a tour of the station.
"A minor operative whose activities are limited to running errands for the terrorist leaders."
Tell her I'll be right there. Major, when you're through feeling underappreciated, perhaps you'd join me in welcoming the Kai aboard.
You say she's never been here before?
She's never even left Bajor before.
Excuse me for saying so, Commander, but she looks preoccupied.
Is something wrong, Opaka?
... Contemplating prophecy.
Interesting you chose this viewport. The wormhole is just out there.

character: Sisko and Bashir step up behind them.BASHIR
quote: It's a spectacular sight to see.
Unfortunately, it can only be seen when a ship enters it or exits, and nothing's scheduled for today.
A shame.
Sisko to O'Brien.
Go ahead Commander.
Prepare the Yangtzee Kiang for launch, Chief. Kira and I are taking the Kai through the wormhole.
Right away, sir.
Thank you.
I didn't want to keep you from your duties, Doctor.
It's a slow day.
All right. This way --
Is the ship ready, Chief?
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: Prepped and ready for departure, Commander. Ma'am --
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: After you.
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: You have a child, don't you?
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: I do. I have a little girl, ma'am.
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: Would you give her this for me.
scene: 6    INT. DOCKING AIRLOCK - ON DOORS OF YANGTZEE KIANG

quote: We'll be entering the wormhole in about a minute.
Thank you again for indulging me.
Not at all, Opaka. You honor us with your presence.
Yangtzee Kiang to DS Nine. Estimating time of return, fourteen hundred hours.
Logged in... We'll expect you then.
Flight stabilization at maximum...
Here we go.
Spectacular, isn't it...
More than I imagined...
My smoothest ride yet, Major.
There's Idran, the closest system. It's a ternary star.
A doorway to the unknown...
The other side of the galaxy, to be precise. The Gamma quadrant is seventy thousand light years from Bajor.
It would take our fastest starship over sixty-seven years to get here.
I'm glad I got the chance to see it.
You'll be seeing what this wormhole means to Bajor in a few years.
If that is to be my fate, Commander.
Should I reverse course?
So soon?
There isn't much else to show you yet.
Prophecy is often vague, Commander, that's why we must test it...
I don't understand, Opaka.
... You may return.
Take us back to the wormhole, Major.
Coming about...
Sensors are picking up a narrow band subspace signal...
What do you make of it?
Just a long stream of statistical data followed by a request for response... but I'm not reading a reply.
Launch a class two probe. We'll follow it up later.
You're not going to investigate it now?
I'm not sure that's a good idea --
Because of my presence?
There's no telling what it may be.
Please, Commander... I don't get out here often.
Can you get a fix on the source, Major?
... Point three-five light years. Bearing... two-two-nine mark four- one.
I guess we'd better take a look.
Engaging warp...
This is definitely the origin of the signal, but I'm having trouble pinpointing the source... It isn't coming from the surface...
There's your answer: a network of artificial satellites -- one of them looks like it's malfunctioning -- its orbit is unstable...
I'd bet the signals we picked up were from the system trying to repair it...
Commander, sensors are indicating lifeforms... localized to a twelve square kilometer area on the moon's surface... They may be humanoid, sir...
Humanoid... can you verify that?
I can't resolve the bio-patterns -- there's too much interference.
Take us in a little closer.
We're being scanned by one of the satellites. I don't like this... it's heading toward us...
Shields up!
... Reading a significant power build- up in the satellite... six hundred megawatts... nine hundred...
... it's firing... !
Shields are down... forward thrusters are gone... we're losing power...
Attempting to compensate with secondary boosters.
Impulse generators failing --
Hold on... we're going down!
Check contingency fuel cell output...
Holding at sixty-five percent...
Doctor, watch the hull temperature.
Aye, sir...
Stabilizing attitude control response.
Pitching up to twenty degrees...
Hull temperature nine hundred C... nine-fifty... eleven hundred...
We're holding profile...
Twelve hundred C... thirteen...
Ejecting antimatter pod...
Pitching up to sixty degrees... prepare for final braking maneuvers...
Brace for impact... !
Pulmonary collapse... her upper thoracic vertebrae have been crushed...
Stay with us, Opaka... stay with us...
... I'm sorry.
Ahn-kay ya, ay-ya vasu. Coh-ma-ra, di-nay-ya.
... We've got company.
Still no contact with Sisko?
Not yet.
They're nearly three hours overdue.
Three and a half.
Opaka's people are on subspace to me every five minutes...
Tell them one of our runabouts found a trace of a warp eddy current... it's gotta be from their ship...
With a little luck, we might be able to determine the direction they were heading...
That's not going to satisfy them on Bajor... you have no idea what the Kai means to them... when they heard Sisko had taken her into the wormhole...
Constable... you tell them we're doing the best we can... okay...
Runabout Pad C...
Have the Bajorans station a ship on the Gamma side, we'll stay in close touch by subspace...
Our first visitors... You are not all the same race.
I am a Bajoran!
I'm Commander Benjamin Sisko. Major Kira Nerys and Doctor Julian Bashir.
A doctor? How... ironic. I'm Golin Shel-la, leader of the Ennis. Why are you here?
We were attacked by one of your satellites. Our ship was damaged and we crashed.
Of course -- but why did you come here?
We were exploring. We've recently discovered a permanent wormhole linking our quadrant of the galaxy to yours. I command a space station at the mouth of that wormhole.
So you know nothing of our home planet... or the punishment?
We're just beginning to explore this sector. As I said, our home is on the other side of the galaxy.
I'm all right --
The hell you are.
She needs treatment. Do you mind?
I apologize for our cautious nature. If you haven't realized... we are at war.
Who are you fighting?
A brutal enemy who attacks at whim. We must maintain a constant vigil. Is this some sort of energy weapon?
(beat, acknowledges reluctantly) Yes...
The Ennis stopped using directed energy weapons centuries ago -- not damaging enough.
Your arrival complicates matters...
We don't plan to be here long.
You expect to repair your ship?
No, but a rescue team is probably on it's way right now.
Like you, they'll have to deal with the defense-net -- and that is beyond my influence.
You don't control the satellites?
We are all prisoners on this moon.
Then, this is a penal colony...
My immediate concern regards your partisanship. By your presence here, you will be considered our ally. Your lives are in danger.
The most recent victims of our enemy -- the Nol-Ennis.
Where are your doctors?
We have none.
You have no medical personnel? How can you survive without...
... We were "thrust" into this situation with few resources. And since you are here under similar circumstances... I was hoping we could help each other.
This should make you feel better...
Major, I'm sorry. I would've done anything --

(uncharacteristically subdued) It's all so senseless. Opaka has always been a symbol of hope for me. Her words gave meaning to our struggle. Now she's dead, her life ends on some unknown moon... ... and for what?
Doctor Bashir will offer any medical assistance he can. But understand that we can't take sides in your battle...
It doesn't matter what I understand if the Nol capture you.
Seems we're in the middle of a pretty ugly war.
I gathered that.
Shel-la says his people will protect us from their enemy in exchange for your services... they have no doctors...
Perhaps I can train some of them in the basics of field triage?
How's the shoulder, Major?
(as if it's a punishment) I'll live...
I still have to run a neuromuscular scan on her when we get back.
Don't count on a quick rescue. This moon is some kind of high security prison colony.
Major... !
Commander, get down!
... Put the phaser away, Kira.
... Her vital signs appear to be normal. But I'm certain she was...
(interrupting, equally stunned) I was there, Doctor...
Opaka, are you aware of what's happened?

(shaking her head, as confused as anyone) The surface was approaching so quickly... I must admit I closed my eyes, Commander... I felt the impact... there was a deafening whine... a wall of heat seemed to pass through me... and then... nothing...
After we crashed, we pulled you from the wreckage... but you were...
-- Dead?
How do you explain this, Doctor?
Although she appears normal... her physiology has been radically altered.
How?
I'm not sure. The tricorder indicates some kind of bio-mechanical presence on the cellular level.
Bio-mechanical? You mean something artificial?
I wish I could tell you. Whatever it is, it seems to be directly controlling her metabolic processes.
Is she in any danger?
I'm sorry to keep saying it, but I just don't know.
If the Runabout's computer were functional, I might be able to do a full analysis.
Commander, over here!
There's still no sign of them on any of the long range scanners...

Not even a transponder signal... if they went down, we should at least get something from their transponder... (pressing panels, frustrated) The warp eddy has traces of meson particle emissions... that makes it a Starfleet power reactor...
The current shows their heading was approximately two-three-zero mark four...
Anything interesting in that direction... ?
(checking, sighs - a big job) An uncharted binary star system...
Guess it's time to chart it...
Setting a new course...
The same as Opaka. Virtually every cell in his body shows signs of this bio-mechanical presence... somehow it has literally brought him back to life...
You've died before.
Many times... too many to count.
Commander, I'd like to return to the Runabout and try to get the computer up and running...
Doctor, we're in the middle of a war...
This could be a breakthrough of unprecedented magnitude...
It's too dangerous...
I'll see to his protection... I'd like to know more about this "breakthrough" myself...
Your doctor acts as though he's seen a miracle.
He's not alone.
If you lived with it as we have, you'd see it as a curse.
How long have you been here?
It feels like an eternity... It's all part of the punishment.
What is this punishment, Shel-la... ?
Everything here has been designed to prolong our suffering.
What was your crime?

The Ennis and the Nol-Ennis sects are ancient enemies. Generation after generation fought the same war. Our planet's leaders were unable to mediate a peace. They finally just sent us all to this moon... and told us that we would serve as an example to the rest of civilization.
How did your fight begin?
Some say it was land. Others say it was water. It is isn't very relevant now...
Then what do you hope to gain by continuing?
Vengeance. Every one of us has seen our families suffer incredibly at the hands of the Nol.
The Nol could say the very same thing...
And probably do.
If you must fight your war, the least you can do is to learn to fight it more effectively...
Major, this is not our...
What do you mean?
... There were no guards at the entrance when we arrived, you have no system to alert your forces of an attack, and your people are obviously unprepared for fighting close- quarter...
That's enough, Major.
We're trapped on this moon with only his forces standing between us and damnation. We've got to defend ourselves to stay alive! When the Nol attack again we have to be ready --
I said, that's enough, Major!
It's not your war, Kira... It's not your war.

We used to defend ourselves better... Safety perimeters, counter-offensives and preemptive strikes... but we realized it was pointless. When you cease to fear death, the rules of war change. You'll understand as the years begin to pass, Major...
Listen to me, Shel-la... our rescue is not going to take years... days, weeks maybe, but they will find us... and then they'll find a way to penetrate the defense-net and transport us out of here...
Then you'll be luckier than we have been...
We'd be willing to transport all of you away from here if that's what you want.
Away from here? To live one life and then die... in peace? To us, that's an ancient prayer that's never been answered, Commander.
You would do this for us?

For both sides... the Ennis and the Nol-Ennis alike... (off Shel-la's skeptical look) After you leave, you can go wherever you want to... just end this nightmare. Stop fighting long enough for all of us to get off this moon...
Zlangco, the leader of the Nol would never agree to a cease-fire...
Ask him...
You don't understand them... all they care about is...

What do you care about? If you want to end the suffering of your people, at least try. Set up a meeting with this Zlangco... talk about this... what do you have to lose, Shel-la -- another day of fighting?
You'll find that it's hopeless. But I will agree to meet... if he will.
I'm not reading a single M Class planet in the system... if they went down anywhere around here, they couldn't have survived...
I'm not sure we can believe the scans, Chief... the star is putting out abnormal levels of delta radiation...
(reacts, checks for himself, sighs) That would foul up our long range scanners...
We'll have to survey each planet one at a time...
Not to mention... ... two dozen or so moons and an asteroid belt... Bloody needle in a haystack...
(murmuring to himself again) Bloody needle in a haystack... what we need is a magnet...
A magnet?
You want to pick a piece of metal out of the straw, you need a magnet...
I don't think I'm following you...

Runabout hulls are made out of metallic composites that interact with magnetic fields... We could send out a few probes to scan the system for those specific magnetic resonance patterns. If Sisko's Runabout is in the system, we might just pick up a fluctuation in the hysteresis curve...
The magnetic deflection of a Runabout hull's going to be extremely weak. The probes'll never be able to detect it.
They will if I can outfit them with a differential magnetomer...
A differential magnetomer?
Uh huh.
I've never heard of a differential magnetomer, Chief. How does it work?
I'll let you know as soon as I've finished making one...
Nice work, Julian... wait till O'Brien hears about this...
scene: 54   INT. RUNABOUT - CLOSE ON FRONT PANEL

quote: I'm surprised. Zlangco has agreed to listen to your proposals...
Good. When.
Right away. We'll meet them at a neutral site near your vessel. We've both agreed to bring no firearms.
What if they use the opportunity to set a trap?
(smiles with respect at Kira) We have taken appropriate precautions, Major... but if you'd like to personally check the security...
Major Kira will be staying here with the Kai...
A shame.
You can't bury it, Kira.
What?
Do you recognize yourself in these people?
Me? Not at all. They're content to die. I've always fought to survive.
I don't want you to have the wrong impression of me, Opaka.
What impression do you think I have?

That... that I... like... any of this. I don't enjoy fighting. Yes, I've spent my life... fighting... for a good cause, our independence, our freedom... but it was brutal and ugly and... I had to be... ... it's over for me... it's not who I am any more. I don't want you to think that I'm... this... violent person... without a conscience... without a soul... it's not who I am.
Don't deny the violence in yourself, Kira. Only when you accept it, can you move beyond it.
I've known nothing but violence since I was child.
In the prophets' eyes, we are all children... Bajor has much to learn from peace...
Opaka, I'm afraid the prophets will never forgive me.
They're just waiting for you to forgive yourself.
Twenty-two minutes into launch. All readings within normal parameters...
Probe "B" approaching planet six... three moons... No change in the hysteresis curve... Probe "C" approaching planet seven... ... no change.
What the hell would they be doing in this system anyway... it's a waste of time... they could be twenty light years from here and we wouldn't have the first clue...
Probe "A" approaching planet three... one moon... Chief...
Probe "A" measuring a point zero- zero-one-two fluctuation in the hysteresis curve...
It's the third planet...
No, look... it isn't... we're picking up something from its moon...
Laying in a new course... full impulse...
Any progress, Doctor?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Yessir, I've got the computer up, more or less... it's processing the data now... but I've already confirmed that these microbes are artificial... rather like nanites in a way... I should have a complete analysis from the computer in a few minutes...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: (beat, re: the fire poles) What's going on?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Talks about a cease fire.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: No kidding... how'd you manage that?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: I told them we'd transport them off this moon.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: (casual humor, looking at the fire) Isn't that a bit like assisting a jailbreak?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: I don't need you to interpret the prime directive for me, Doctor.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: I only meant...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Whatever crimes they've committed have been paid for a hundred times over. They've been altered somehow and abandoned by their world... I believe the Federation would recognize them as separate and unique.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Yessir. I... should be checking on that analysis...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: So you are the leader of the aliens...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Benjamin Sisko, Commander of a Federation space station...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Federation?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: What does it matter to us, Zlangco?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: It matters to me.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: The Federation is made up of over a hundred planets who have allied themselves for mutual scientific, cultural and defensive benefits. The mission that my people and I are on is to explore the galaxy.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Such a noble purpose... there will be no reward for our release, you know...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: You're being a fool as usual...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: A fool who can always outwit you, Shel-la... as I have proven over and over again...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: If you care to die once more, all you need to do is ask...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: If you've had enough of this, then make your leaders stop and listen... you are fighting a war for the sake of war... your only reason to live is to make each other suffer. If you've suffered enough, then make your leaders stop.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: I'm not here to be a mediator... but if you ask me for an alternative... I'll give you one.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: We're listening.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: In a matter of days, when our rescue party arrives, I can arrange to transport you and your people off this moon... if both sides can simply cooperate until then...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: They will resettle us on different planets, Zlangco...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: If that's what you wish...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: The two of you seem to have discussed this plan in detail...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Of course. His crew has been with us for two days...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Explain why you choose to ally yourselves with the Ennis...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: We have allied ourselves with no one...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: One of your people fired some kind of weapon at us...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: We were defending ourselves...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: I think you're lying... I don't know the alien. But I know Shel-la. I know how his mind works. I promise you this is an Ennis trick to lure our entire population out of hiding so they can be slaughtered...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: That's not...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Fine... then the Ennis will surely be willing to make the first gesture of peace... let them bring all of their people out in the open first... to prove their honorable intentions...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Do you honestly think I would let a single Nol escape this moon alive?
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: No more than I would let an Ennis go free...
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: Sorry, Commander, but I've discovered we can't afford to die here -- not even once.
scene: 60   EXT. MOON SURFACE - NEAR RUNABOUT CRASH SITE

quote: It's some kind of artificial satellite system... that's what our probe must have picked up...
Our sensors are reading lifeforms on the surface, Chief... I think some of them are human...
If the ship's down there, why wouldn't the transponder be sending out a...
We're being scanned...
Increasing orbital altitude...
Why?

I'm thinkin' the only thing that could block out a transponder signal is a broad band damping field... and that would require a low altitude satellite system like this one... and then suddenly we're being scanned by these satellites and I'm thinking...
... maybe they had something to do with our missing Runabout...
Exactly. (checking sensors, nods) See, they're putting out a mutual induction field that would block ninety-nine percent of all transmissions to and from the surface...
Is there any way for us to get a com line through the field?
I've got one percent to work with, don't I?
The analysis is very clear. Once these microbes restore a body after death, that body becomes permanently dependent on them for all cellular functions...
Permanently...
It gets worse... The designers made them environment specific... If the microbes are removed from this ecosystem, they'll stop functioning...
So, if we transport anyone off this moon, we'd kill them.
I'm afraid so.
The Kai?
... Rio Grande to Sisko... do you read me... ? This is O'Brien, come in...
Go ahead, Chief... I can barely read you...
Is everyone all right?
We're alive. But the Yangtzee Kiang was destroyed.
Will you be able to beam us up?
Not quite yet, Commander... we've got to find a way to penetrate this network of satellites... they're making it impossible to lock on to anything down there...
Understood. By the way, those satellites will come after you if you get too close... they're armed... one of them cut us down without any trouble at all...
Yeah, we figured as much.
Let me know before you're ready to make an attempt...
Acknowledged. Rio Grande out.
... We have to talk to the Kai.
Is there a cease-fire?
Neither side took it seriously.
I'm not at all surprised. You were right, Kira. They don't know how to do anything else but die -- they've forgotten how to live.
The Rio Grande just made contact. O'Brien and Dax are in orbit.
They're working on a way to penetrate the defense system...
I'll be staying, Commander.
What... ?
It's the answer to all the prophecies of my life...
It's the wrong answer, Opaka... you can't stay here...

I didn't know how or why... but when we came through the wormhole, I knew I wouldn't be returning. You must tell our people, Kira, that I have answered the call of the prophets... I have been brought here because it is time for these people to begin their healing process... ... just as you were brought here to begin yours.
You know, all we really need to do is find a way to create a gap in the net...
Maybe a photon would destroy one of the satellites...

Maybe. But you'd think they'd build a defense network with that in mind... hell, shoot one and the rest might swarm up like Vayan horn flies. We should go for something simpler... all I need is about a fifteen percent wider opening in the net... (an idea, thoughtful, to com) Rio Grande to Sisko...
Go ahead, Chief.
We're going to try to poke a hole up here, sir, if you're about ready to end your stay...
Only three of us will be coming back... Kai Opaka is remaining...
Benjamin, please confirm... did you say we're not transporting the Kai?
That's correct. I'll explain later.
We'll need a few minutes, Commander. Rio Grande out.
Leaving without us?
My analysis of the microbes that keep you alive showed that if you were to leave the moon, you would die...
So there is no end.
Commander, I find myself caught in a moral dilemma. As much as I'm dedicated to the preservation of life, I wonder if we shouldn't help these people end this torture...
How could you do that?

Anything that is programmed can be reprogrammed. If I can disable the mechanism in these microbes, they would no longer function when someone was killed... these people would be allowed to finally die...
You've seen our lives here. Please... it is the only solution left. Give us a way to reprogram these microbes... and it will mean the end to this war.
You really think the fear of death would stop the fighting? It never has in any other war.
No... but it will allow us to finally win. Wipe out the Nol for good. On this world, your disabled microbes would be the ultimate weapon, Doctor -- one that we could use to truly destroy our enemies.
Rio Grande to Sisko... stand by for transport...
Ready.
Coordinates set.
Launching probe.
Twelve seconds to intercept...
Come on, come on, go for it...
One of the satellites is breaking orbit... moving toward the probe...
That's it...
The satellite is showing a power buildup... about eight hundred megawatts...
Probe destroyed...
Rio Grange to Sisko. Trying to lock on, Commander...
Establishing pattern lock...
Wait... you can't leave without giving us the...
Energize when ready, Chief...
Opaka... if we can ever find a way...
My work is here now, Commander... But your pagh and mine will cross again...
Energizing...
The sounds of fighting continue over a black screen...
... So there I was, fighting the toughest battle of my life. I looked around hoping to spot a friendly face... only to discover my colleagues were gone... (a beat for dramatic effect) I was... alone.

I admit, for a moment there, I considered giving up. I could feel the seconds ticking away... panic building up inside me. I knew my only chance was to trust my instincts. I closed my eyes... ... took a deep breath... and just like that it came to me. The answer I was waiting for... A pericardial membrane. I looked down and wrote it into my computer terminal, just as the buzzer sounded ending the exam. And that, I suppose, is the stuff of which salutatorians are made.
Salutatorian?
I mistook a pre-ganglionic fiber for a post-ganglianic nerve during the orals or I would have been valedictorian. It was a trick question.
Fascinating.
Not nearly as fascinating as...
Doctor Bashir... Chief O'Brien... report to landing pad five immediately.
Bad timing.
There'll be another time.
Starfleet medical finals... gets them every time.
It's no use.
Chief, we've got to get this hatch open. Lieutenant Dax and Ensign Pauley are trapped in there.
The Runabout barely made it back through the wormhole. By the time they docked, power levels were near zero.
There's not even enough juice left in the ship to release the servos.
Life support's down and oxygen levels have dropped dangerously low.
We'll have to burn through.
Forget it Major. That hatch is made of duranium composite. It would take you an hour to get through.
We don't have that much time. That's odd. How many passengers did you say were on the Ganges?
Two.
I'm reading three.
We need to get power to the hatch servos. (pointing to the service module) Major, hand me that EPI capacitor.
Top shelf, all the way to the left.
Stand clear.
Give her a go.
I'm fine, check the others.
Vash.
That's right... ?
Miles O'Brien... From the Enterprise.
Yes of course.
What are you doing on the Ganges?
We found her in the Gamma Quadrant. She's been there for over two years.
(reacts, glances at Sisko) Two years... ?
Doctor, we better get these people over to the Infirmary.
Right this way.
How did you get to the Gamma Quadrant two years ago?
A friend dropped me off.
Will I live?
You're fine. In fact, you're in remarkable shape.
Thank you, Doctor. I try.
I'd say you've managed quite well for someone who's been out of contact with civilization for over two years.
I'd hardly call the Gamma Quadrant uncivilized. Some of the cultures I've encountered have histories dating back millions of years.
Really... ? I'd love to hear about them. We have no idea what's beyond the wormhole...
Perhaps I'll write a book...
It's certain to be a best-seller around here... Well, no sign of disease or malnutrition, no parasitic infections...
You sound disappointed.
I am. Now I don't have any reason to keep you here.
You almost make me wish I wasn't feeling well.
... And she claims she knew nothing about the wormhole... ?
She was very surprised when I told her about it. I don't think she ever expected to see this part of the galaxy again.
How could she get there in the first place if she didn't go through the wormhole?
She didn't want to talk about it. Said it was a personal matter.
This doesn't make sense. A human alone in the Gamma Quadrant for two years. Let's check her background. See what we can find out about her.
She claims to be an archaeologist.
That's a good place to start.
You're sure this place is safe?
The Assay office is the most secure area on the station.
The chambers are surrounded on all sides by individual force fields.
How are the locks controlled?
Once you secure a chamber, it can't be opened except with your personal authorization code, combined with a verified retinal print.
Cardassian MK-seven scanner?
MK-twelve with an L-ninety enhanced resolution filter.
I suppose it'll have to do.

Computer, begin inventory for cubicle nineteen. One statue, stone, thirty- odd centimeters tall, approximately twenty kilograms... Assorted gems... Gold necklace... One dagger, bronze and gold, about twenty-five centimeters.
Beautiful. I've never seen anything quite like it. Some kind of Promethean Quartz?
That's what I thought at first, but it's molecular density and refraction index are much higher.
(to Vash, admiring the Geode) Remarkable.
(continuing, to computer) End inventory.
Please enter an access code.
I'll be back to pick everything up tomorrow. I've booked passage on the Mulzirak Transport.
You're not leaving us so soon, are you?
I'm afraid so.
The Daystrom Institute will be very disappointed.
The Daystrom Institute?
Their scientists are anxious to hear about life in the Gamma Quadrant.
Every place you've been, everything you've seen, no matter how insignificant, could prove important. Including how you got there.
I'm sorry, Commander, but that's a...
Personal matter.
So now the Daystrom Institute is interested in me. That's ironic.
Professor Woo seemed especially eager to speak to you again.
Did he really? I suppose he told you that he suspended my membership from the Institute's Archaeological Council.
On two occasions. Something about the illegal sale of artifacts...
Let's just say when it comes to choosing between science and profit... I'll choose profit every time.
I think the professor is hoping in this case you'll make an exception.
You know, I haven't been back to Earth in... it must be twelve years.
Here's your chance. I could arrange passage...
I think, I'd like that.
I don't understand it, Commander. I can't find anything wrong with her. This ship's completely functional.
It didn't look that way this morning.
Oh, don't get me wrong. The power reserves are empty, the inertial damping fields are barely operating and the warp drive containment field is on the verge of collapse.
But...
But there's nothing wrong with any of them. Once we put power back into the Ganges, she should be fully operational.
Did you check the central power linkages?
Yes Sir. I ran a level one diagnostic. Everything checks out. I can't explain it. It's like something tapped into the ship's systems and drained them dry.
Tell me Chief, how well do you know this Vash woman?
Hardly at all. Only met her that one time she was aboard the Enterprise.
What was she doing there?
Well Sir, Vash and Captain Picard were friends... close friends... if you follow my meaning. Seems they met on Risa a few years back.
I figure she must be a special woman... to be friends with the Captain and all.
Somehow she doesn't seem to be his type.
The Captain likes a good challenge, sir.
Status report?
We suffered a broad spectrum power drain.
The power transfer is completely inoperative. The energy was drawn out faster than it could handle.
I'll have to replace the entire unit.
Chief, are you reading any graviton flux around the transfer systems.
I am detecting a low level graviton disturbance... How did you know?
That's exactly what happened when we lost power on the Ganges.
These were originally Cardassian living quarters. The bed may take some getting use to.
As an archaeologist, I've spent half my life sleeping in tents. To me any bed is a luxury.
You've obviously never slept on a Cardassian mattress.
If you need anything just ask the computer.
Thanks, Chief. By the way, how's Jean-Luc?
The Captain? Last time I saw him he was fine.
Well, now that I'm back, I'll have to look him up.
Really, Vash, I can't believe you're still pining for Jean-Luc, that self righteous do-gooder.
I should have listened to him when he warned me about you...
You're hurt, so you lash out. I understand. But be of good cheer. I bring wonderful news. I'm back. I can see now it was cruel of me to leave you.
I'm back. I can see now it was cruel of me to leave you.
That's very touching. But you didn't leave me, I left you.
You left me, I left you... Details, mere details. The important thing is we're back together again... a team... joined at the hip...
Not a chance.
Come now, you know you missed me.
Don't flatter yourself.
I thought first we'd visit the Teleris Cluster... look in on the cloud dancers of Mundahla. Or maybe head over to the Lantar Nebula to view the Sampalo relics on Hoek Four.
Not interested.
I know. Vadris Three. Charming little world. The natives think they're the only intelligent life in the galaxy...
No.
Oh, very well. You choose this time.
I choose never to go anywhere with you again, Q...
You don't know what you'll be missing. When we started this little partnership, I promised to take you places no human had ever seen...
And you have. Thank you... and goodbye.
Two years in the Gamma Quadrant hardly qualifies as a grand tour of the universe. There's still the Delta Quadrant to explore, not to mention all the other galaxies.
It's over Q. I want you out of my life. You're arrogant, overbearing and you think you know everything.
But I do know everything.
That makes it even worse.
Okay... fine... I understand... I hear you. What is it you real want?
I want... the life I had before I met you.
Ah yes, a stellar life indeed. The eminent Vash. Barred from the Royal Museum of Epsilon Hydra Seven, persona non grata on Betazed. Wanted Dead on Myrmidon for stealing the Crown of the First Mother.
Dead or alive.
Preferably dead. It's a wonder you haven't offended every sentient race in the galaxy.
You're the one who almost got me killed on Errikang Seven. And they weren't exactly thrilled to see you on Brax either. What did they call you there? "The God of Lies?"
They meant it affectionately.
Come in.
Go away.
Go away.
Q, bring him back.
What business could you possibly have with that repulsive little troll?
I don't know. You didn't give him time to tell me. Now bring him back this instant.
Oh, very well.
Can I help you?
My name is Quark. It's come to my attention that you have access to certain items. Items that could perhaps turn a tidy profit.
I'm listening.
For a percentage, I might be able to arrange a buyer for your trinkets. Perhaps an auction.
I'll only accept payment in gold- press latinum.
I'll shower you in it. (a beat, re: their split) Fifty-fifty?
Mister Quark, I believe you're trying to take advantage of me.
Mmmm. You have a talent for oo-mox.
So I've been told.
I will not be distracted by your feminine wiles. I demand forty percent.
All right, thirty.
What magnificent cartilage.
Twenty-two and don't stop.
You've got a deal.
I expect you to make all the necessary arrangements.
(admiring her business acumen) Oh, you're good. You're very, very good.
How perfectly vile. If that's the kind of company you kept before you met me, it's no wonder you ended up with Picard.
Go away.
Enter.
My, aren't we the hub of activity?
I'm sorry. Am I interrupting anything?
Not at all, Doctor. Come in.
Thank you, and please, call me Julian.
Julian. Is this a medical visit?
To tell the truth, I tried to come up with some official reason for dropping by, but your excellent health has robbed me of any excuses.
Well, that didn't seem to stop you.
I thought I could contribute to your good health by buying you dinner. Quark's makes a lovely couscous. And the company, I hope, might be mildly entertaining.
Sounds like fun.
But first I need to freshen up. Can I meet you in say, twenty minutes?
Those twenty minutes will feel like an eternity.
These mating rituals you humans indulge in really are quite disgusting.
Get out.
You know you don't mean that.
Out.
You're making a terrible mistake. You'd be lost without me.
I can take care of myself.
Can you really? We'll see about that.
Just a cup of mint tea.
You're making a terrible mistake.
Why? Have the replicators malfunctioned again?
I'm talking about Vash. Stay away from her.
My god, you're an impertinent waiter.
I'm a friend... with some friendly advice. Vash is nothing but trouble.
Really, I don't think it's any of your business. In fact, I'm meeting her for dinner now...
Are you sure you're feeling up to it? You look tired.
I feel fine.
You look tired. Very, very tired.
Funny, I am feeling a bit spent. Maybe I should go lie down for a few minutes.
Hopefully by yourself, for a change.
Bloody hell.
Sir, the Klingon scout ship has departed docking bay eleven.
Good. I'll tell Odo he can relax now.
Sir, we've got a problem. I just saw Q on the Promenade.
Q? Here?
What's Q?
A powerful and extremely unpredictable entity. I was at a Starfleet briefing on him, two years ago.
He's a blasted menace, is what he is.
What does he want with us?
Whatever it is, you can be sure we won't like it.
You might ask Vash.
Why Vash?
They know each other.
From the Enterprise?
I believe they actually met in Sherwood Forest. (off Sisko's puzzled look) One of the little jokes Q played on the Enterprise crew.
Main power grid has dropped eighty percent.
Sensors are reading a massive graviton build-up.
How long to get us back up to full power?
It's already beginning to normalize.
If we have one of these outages during a docking procedure, we could lose an entire pylon.
I've double-checked every system. For the first time in a month, there's nothing wrong with any of them... it's got to be Q. Another one of his stupid jokes.
I'm not laughing.
I figure we'd auction this off last.
Interesting... but hardly of any intrinsic value.
Really? I thought it was the best piece in the collection.
Obviously my associates have more sophisticated tastes than you're used to. But just so it's not a total loss, I'll take it off your hands for say... seven bars of gold-press latinum.
It's worth fifty times as much.
Ridiculous... All right, eighteen bars, but you must swear never to tell a soul about my foolish generosity.
(takes the box from Quark) If you want it you're going to have to be a lot more foolish than that.
All right. Thirty. (he reaches for the box) Now give it to me.
Bidding will start at two hundred bars of latinum.
I can't decided which is more intoxicating, this Gamzian wine or your negotiating skills.
We need to talk.
The lady and I are having a private conversation.
It can wait.
Commander, have you seen that Doctor of yours? He was supposed to meet me here half an hour ago...
(interrupting, purposeful) Tell me about Q.
I'll tell you anything you want to know, Commander. Just answer one question... Is Starfleet penalizing you or did you actually request such a dismal command.
I want you off this station.

Let's not be hasty, my happy-go- lucky friend, this dreary little gulag could use a little color, a little excitement. And who better to provide it than... moi? Though I must say I approve of your new tailor.
I'm not impressed by your parlor tricks. These power outages are going to stop... right now.
Why tell me? Oh, I see. Go ahead, blame Q if it makes you feel any better. I suppose it's my fate to be the galaxy's whipping boy. Heavy is the burden of being me.
If you're looking for sympathy, you've come to the wrong place.
Actually, what I had in mind was some witty repartee, but I see I'm not going to get any of that either. At least, your beloved Jean-Luc knows how to turn a phrase...
At least, your beloved Jean-Luc knows how to turn a phrase...
Take the hint, Q... no one wants you around.
Really, Vash, this playing hard to get is growing tedious.
You might keep in mind that I am the Q and you are the lowly human. I will decide when this partnership ends. (to both Vash and Sisko) Do you understand?
(to Q, as the room reacts) Why don't you and I continue this discussion in private?
An excellent idea.
You're right. This is much better.
Sisko to Ops.
All gone.
Bring them back, Q. Now.
Or what? You'll thrash me? Shall we settle this mano a mano?
Marquis of Queensberry Rules?
What?
Fisticuffs, pugilism, the manly art of self-defense. Isn't it wonderfully barbaric? Go on. Take a poke at me. That is what you want to do, isn't it?
Don't tempt me.
I'll wager five bars of latinum on Sisko.
You're on.
Come on, fight back. This is supposed to be brutal.
You can pay me out of your profits from the auction.
You hit me... Picard never hit me.
I'm not Picard.
Indeed not. You're much easier to provoke. How fortunate for me.
He's never going to let me go. Unless you can help...
I wouldn't get my hopes up. It was a lucky punch.
Not again.
Damn it, Q. Enough is enough.
(over the roar of the wind) We're losing atmosphere.
Decompression protocol - Raise the confinement shields.
Shields up.
Damage report.
We've got a minor hull breach in one of the upper bulkheads.
I'm getting reports of hull fractures throughout the station. Emergency systems appear to be functioning. Repair crews are responding.
The breach was caused by some kind of focused graviton pulse.
Every time we've had a power drain, it's been followed by an increase in the graviton field. If this continues we could wind up with a breach in one of our reactor cores. We'd lose half the station.
Maybe it's time to open negotiations with Q?
I'm not convinced that Q's behind this.
Playing with the lights and punching holes in the hull doesn't strike me as his style.
You wanted to see me? Make it quick. I've got important business.
Yes, I know. You're auctioning off some artifacts from the Gamma Quadrant.
You were eavesdropping on my conversation with Vash. What were you this time? The table? One of the chairs? The wine bottle?
When are you going to realize that you have no secrets from me?
I have nothing to hide. I'm selling quality merchandise to a select clientele.
What makes them so select?
They're all ridiculously wealthy... and not too bright.

I'll never understand this obsession with accumulating material wealth. You spend your entire life plotting and scheming to acquire more and more possessions, until your living areas are bursting with useless junk. Then you die and your relatives sell everything and start the cycle all over again.
Isn't there anything you desire?
I have my work. What more do I need?
(eyes light up at the thought) A suit of the finest Andorian silk? A ring of pure Surax? A complete set of Tanesh pottery?
(on Odo's lack of response) How about a latinum plated bucket to sleep in?
Ah, I'm so glad you're packed. I hope you said good-bye to all your new friends.
I don't have time for this now.
You've led a charmed life these past two years... under my benevolent protection.
I can take care of myself.
Can you really? Remember that bug bite you got on Erabus Prime? If I hadn't been there...
I am not going with you.
It's over, Q.
(to Vash, as if nothing has happened) I'll leave you now to reconsider my offer of friendship.
Station Log. Stardate xxxxx.x. The station's power is continuing to be drained and converted into gravitons. At this rate, our life support systems will fail in fourteen hours.
Sir, we'll never find the source of the power drain using these bloody Cardassian internal sensors. They're just not sensitive enough.
Is there anyway to recalibrate them?
It would take days. We just don't have the time.
What if we make the power drain easier to detect? If we flood the station with ionized tridium gas, we should be able to trace the particle flow to the source.
Tridium? Isn't that pretty toxic.
Only when it's highly concentrated. We would use a very small amount.
Do it. If we can't get this under control in the next eight hours, we'll begin evacuation procedures
Still chasing your own tail? Picard and his lackeys would have solved all this techno-babble hours ago. No wonder you're not commanding a Starship.
Security to OPS.
My, aren't we the fiesty little go getter. I'd keep my eye on this one. Chances are, she's after your job.
Why don't you do something constructive for a change? Like torment the Cardassians.
O'Brien... (on Q's lack of recognition) From the Enterprise.
The Enterprise. Ah yes. Weren't you one of the little people?
Quite a motley crew you've assembled here, Benji. My advice is to evacuate now and save all this pointless guesswork.
Q, either tell us what's going on or get the hell out of the way.

I'll tell you what's going on. While you're conducting futile experiments, Vash is down below engaging in base commerce and setting Federation ethics back two hundred years. Believe me, she's far more dangerous to you than I am.
Kolos, my friend. I don't know which pleases me more, your smiling face or your overflowing purse.
Quark, you obsequious toad, your so- called Gamma Quadrant merchandise had better be legitimate or I'll toss you out the nearest airlock.
No cause for alarm, each piece comes complete with a statement of authenticity from Vash herself, the Federation's foremost expert on the Gamma Quadrant.
In that case, stop snivelling and give me a synthale.
Are they all that pleasant?
I don't care about their manners. The important thing is they're honest collectors in antiquities, every one.
How honest?
As honest as you and I.
We better keep a close eye on them.
My dear, I've been thinking, what would you say to a permanent partnership? With your knowledge of the Gamma Quadrant, and my business connections, we could make a fortune.
Sorry, Quark, I've slept in my last tent. I'm looking forward to a nice quiet life back on Earth.
You won't last a month. You're like me. You live for excitement, adventure, profit.
Not anymore.
Would you care to make a wager on that?
The graviton field has increased by sixty percent.
How soon can we begin the sensor sweep... ?
Not until we've increased tridium levels to one part per million... it should only be another seven, eight minutes...
Commander... we're being pulled out of our normal position.
Could it have something to do with this graviton field?
I don't understand it...
Use the control thrusters to stabilize our position.
Firing thrusters...
We're still moving.
If the graviton field is feeding off the station's power, maybe we can cut its supply by shutting down the reactors.
Put life support on emergency backup. Take everything else off-line.
We're still being pulled out of position...
What's our heading?
Bearing one-five-seven, mark one- three.
Straight into the wormhole.
There's a definite imbalance in the graviton field that corresponds with our trajectory. I think that's what's pulling us toward the wormhole.
Could the field be generated from the wormhole itself?
Not likely. The field symmetry doesn't match the wormhole's subspace emissions.
If it's not the wormhole, and it's not Q, what the hell is causing it... ?
It doesn't match anything in Federation or Bajoran records.
One thing's for sure. Our sensors aren't detecting anything within a hundred kilometers. Whatever's creating the graviton field has to be inside the station.
Then we'll find out what it is if we can trace the power drain...
Sisko to Ops.
Go ahead, Commander...
How long before we can begin the trace?
(checks a monitor, presses a panel) Tridium levels will be at a sufficient concentration in one minute.
We're on our way.
I tell you, something's wrong.
Calm down, Kolos. This is a normal power recalibration procedure. Nothing to worry about.
Doesn't seem normal to me...
Shhh. Now, as you know, payments must be in gold press latinum, and all transactions are final. Remember, bid high and bid often.

Ladies and gentlemen, our first item is a statue from the Gamma Quadrant's Verath System. First I suppose I should talk a little bit about the Verathan civilization, which reached its height some thirty thousand years ago...
What are you doing?
Placing the statue in its historical context.
Here, give me that. This isn't the Daystrom Institute. Watch closely.
Friends, have you ever purchased a one-of-a-kind artifact only to discover some other collector has six more just like it?
Well, now you can avoid that kind of embarrassment.
It's rare... it's beautiful... it's a Gamma Quadrant original and it can be yours, for the right price. Bidding will start at ten bars of gold press latinum.
(responding to hand signals) I see ten. Fifteen. Sixteen. Who'll say seventeen and be the first to own a piece of the Gamma Quadrant.
Tridium levels throughout the station have reached one part per million.
Initiating sensor sweep...
We can rule out the docking ring...
The tridium gas seems to be draining toward the central core...
Where in the central core?
Let me see if I can get a more precise reading...
It's not clear enough. I can't pinpoint the exact location.
Based on our current trajectory, we'll hit the wormhole in eighteen minutes...
What the hell could be pulling us into the wormhole... Do we have time to transfer auxiliary power to the deflectors, Chief?
Sir, there's not enough power left to make any difference... if we get sucked into that wormhole, we'll be in a billion pieces by the time we reach the Gamma Quadrant.
Sold to Kolos for thirty-six bars of gold press latinum.
Next we have a... a dagger, studded with some very interesting looking gems. Think of it as both a weapon and an investment. Bidding will start at forty.
Forty. Forty-two, forty-five. Don't hold back, you know you want it, give me fifty... Fifty. We have fifty.

I hate to interrupt such a thrilling display of naked avarice, but I feel it's only fair to warn you that the station is hurtling toward its doom. It's very unlikely any of you will survive to enjoy your purchases.
Just thought I'd mention it.
Ladies and gentlemen, I assure you, everything is under control.
Drinks for everyone.
And free use of the holosuites at the conclusion of the auction.

I don't think I realized (speaking in the until this moment how evil background) you really are... you would Now, if I'm not mistaken, kill all these people to get bidding was halted at... even with me. sixty bars of gold press Latinum. Do I hear sixty- Q five? Seventy... Come on, I must admit, the thought a piece of the Gamma had occurred to me. But Quadrant to bury in the the fact is, this station heart of your most hated is in enough trouble without rival. Eighty, that's the me. I will, however, gladly spirit. Eighty-five... save you. All you have to think of it, Kolos, do is ask. wouldn't this make a perfect companion piece to VASH that statue you I'll take my chances purchased... Ninety... with the others. Ninety-five... Can we break a hundred... A Q hundred... You make me As you wish. Now, if you proud. A hundred and don't mind, I'll just sit five... Do I hear any here and watch. I've never other bids... Final seen a space station torn call... sold to my cousin apart by a wormhole before. Stol for one hundred and five bars of gold press latinum.

Q five? Seventy... Come on, I must admit, the thought a piece of the Gamma had occurred to me. Q hundred... You make me As you wish. Now, if you proud. A hundred and don't mind, I'll just sit five... Do I hear any here and watch. I've never other bids... Final seen a space station torn call... sold to my cousin apart by a wormhole before. Stol for one hundred and five bars of gold press latinum.
latinum.
Listen, the tridium almost worked the first time. Maybe we didn't use enough. Why don't we increase the concentration in the central core?
It might work. But in four years, we'd all be dead from tridium poisoning.
Wait a minute... of course... Bring the reactors back on line...
The reactors? But they'll just feed more energy to the graviton field.
If we generate enough energy, it should create a power drain big enough to trace.
It might also push us faster into the wormhole... a lot faster...
It's a chance we've gotta take. Bring us to full power, Mister O'Brien. Everything you've got.
Aye, sir.
Sold to Rul the Obscure for a hundred and fifty-one latinum bars. And now, our final item. And I think you'll agree with me it was well worth the wait.
Bidding will start at two hundred bars of gold press latinum.
Two hundred. Can I get two fifty? Two fifty. Three hundred anyone?
Three hundred bars.
Three hundred and fifty? Four hundred? Four hundred... Five... Five hundred and twenty...
Six hundred bars of gold press latinum.
It's not in any of the crossover bridges... or the habitat ring... it's in the upper core.
Three minutes, fourteen seconds... to the wormhole... we're picking up speed.
I've got it. The power drain's coming from the Promenade.
You have Ops, Chief...
One thousand bars of latinum... Going once, going twice, going...
Two thousand. For you, my dear. Think of it as a good-bye present.
And what a magnificent gesture it is. Two thousand.
Twenty-five hundred.
Twenty-five hundred... and one.
This way.
Three thousand bars of latinum. My final offer.
Three thousand bars.
A million.
A million bars of gold press latinum.
Over here.
(trying to wrap things up) A million... Going once...
It's by that podium.
(seeing Sisko getting closer) A million going twice.
That's it.
Three times...
This auction is over...
Sold.
Chief, shut down the reactors. We found it.
And about time, too.
Sorry, all transactions are final. This item now belongs to that gentleman over there.
I'm reading a massive graviton build up inside this container... it's increasing exponentially. We've got to get it off the station now...
Chief, lock on to my combadge... prepare to transport it five hundred meters off the docking ring...
Energize.
Station log, Stardate xxxxx.x. With the embryonic lifeform off the station, graviton levels have returned to normal. We've used the control thrusters to return the station to its original position.

So... you're off to the Daystrom Institute. I bet you can hardly wait... Long boring lectures... Endless conferences... Whining students dogging your every step... Sounds delightful. Of course... No, you wouldn't be interested.
In what?
I hear they've uncovered the ruins of a Rokai provincial capital on Tartaras Five. If you could obtain some Rokain artifacts...
Forget it, Quark. I'm going back to Earth.
An abysmal place.
Tartaras Five?
Earth. Don't get me wrong. A thousand years ago it had character...
The Crusades, the Spanish Inquisition, Watergate. But now... it's mind- numbingly dull.
Please, by all means, don't come with me.
Trust me, you'd be a lot happier poking around the ruins on Tartaras Five.
I don't need your advice. You really think I... A beat.
You know, I still feel I owe you a million bars of gold press latinum.
Keep it. Just give me back my life.
You'll regret it if I do.
I'm willing to take that chance.

All right. If you insist. But things won't be the same without you. When I look at a gas nebula, all I see is a cloud of dust, but seeing the universe through your eyes allowed me to experience... wonder. I'm going to miss that.
I guess, in some ways, I'm going to miss you too.
Well, maybe I'll drop in on you sometime.
God, I hope not.
So Quark, what's the quickest way to Tartaras Five?
I feel like I've slept for days. Did I miss something?
I'm not what a lot of people think...
I mean if you're a dabo girl, you know, you get a reputation...
Miss Sarda, why don't tell me exactly what happened? When did you start having trouble with Quark...
About five minutes after I got off the ship...
He immediately made sexual advances.
He said it was part of the job.
And what did you say?
I told him I'd wear the costume and entertain the gamblers... but to keep his Ferengi knuckles to himself...
But that didn't stop him... ?
No, he said again that it was part of the job.
He showed me my employment agreement... see? There it is in the Ferengi print, on page twenty- one, sub-section twelve... paragraph "D"...
You're telling me the contract you signed requires you to...
I guess I should have read it more carefully... I'm not a legal expert, Commander...
I'm not a legal expert either, but I can assure you, after I talk to Quark, he won't hold you, or anyone else, to this provision of...
Commander, sensors are picking up elevated neutrino readings. Something's coming through the wormhole...
Are any of the transports due back?
Not according to our logs.
Put us on yellow alert. Excuse me...
It doesn't match anything in Starfleet files.
I'm getting readings of a massive energy flux. It could be damaged.
Sensors indicate a single humanoid lifeform onboard.
Hail it.
Aye, Sir. Hail acknowledged. Response coming in.
On screen.
Welcome to the Alpha Quadrant. I'm Commander Benjamin Sisko of the United Federation of Planets.
Alpha quadrant?
You have passed through a wormhole into a new part of the galaxy...
